https://s3.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-us-east/content/pii:S1381116914002969/gr8/HIGHRES/image/jpeg/c66b096d1cb1dbdeddb05e6257357dc5/gr8_lrg.jpg gr8 gr8_lrg.jpg jpg 96613 815 1118 IMAGE-HIGH-RES MOLCAA 9186 S1381-1169(14)00296-9 10.1016/j.molcata.2014.07.004 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 XRD patterns of Cu-ZSM-5 samples. Fig. 2 27Al NMR spectra of Cu-ZSM-5 samples. Fig. 3 SEM image (A) and TEM image (B) of Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets. Fig. 4 (A) DRIFT spectra for room-temperature CO adsorption on Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets pretreated in situ in He at each temperature. (B) DRIFT spectra for room-temperature CO adsorption on fresh Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets (a), spent Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets (b), fresh conventional Cu-ZSM-5 (c), spent conventional Cu-ZSM-5 (d) pretreated in situ in He at 400°C. Fig. 5 H2-TPR profiles of Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets and conventional Cu-ZSM-5. Fig. 6 O2-TPD results of Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets and conventional Cu-ZSM-5. Fig. 7 N2O conversions on Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets and conventional Cu-ZSM-5 as a function of reaction temperature, either in the absence or in the presence of 5% O2. Fig. 8 N2O conversions on Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets and conventional Cu-ZSM-5 as a function of reaction time on stream. Conditions: 5000ppmN2O, balance He, 475°C. Table 1 Chemical composition and textural property of different samples. Sample Si/Al a Cu b (wt%) S BET c (m2/g) V total d (cm3/g) V meso e (cm3/g) Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets 39 1.48 410 0.55 0.45 Conventional Cu-ZSM-5 36 1.47 381 0.25 0.12 a Determined by XRF analysis. b Determined by ICP analysis. c BET surface area. d Total volume adsorbed at P/P 0 =0.99. e Mesopore volume calculated from BJH method. Table 2 H2-TPR data of two Cu-ZSM-5 catalysts. Catalytic decomposition of N2O over Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets Wei Zou a b 1 Pengfei Xie a 1 Weiming Hua a Yangdong Wang b Dejin Kong b Yinghong Yue a ⁎ Zhen Ma c ⁎ Weimin Yang b Zi Gao a a Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Department of Chemistry, Fudan University, Shanghai 200433, PR China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Department of Chemistry, Fudan University Shanghai 200433 PR China b Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology SINOPEC, Shanghai 201208, PR China Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology SINOPEC Shanghai 201208 PR China c Shanghai Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Particle Pollution and Prevention (LAP3), Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Fudan University, Shanghai 200433, PR China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Particle Pollution and Prevention (LAP3), Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Fudan University Shanghai 200433 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 21 65642409; fax: +86 21 65641740. 1 These authors are co-first authors; they contributed to this work equally. Graphical abstract ZSM-5 nanosheets were prepared using [C18H37-N+(CH3)2-C6H12-N+(CH3)2-C6H13]Br2 as a template and then ion-exchanged with Cu cations. The catalytic performance of the obtained Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets in N2O decomposition was investigated and compared with that of conventional Cu-ZSM-5. Higher activity as well as better stability was observed for Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets although the Cu contents of the catalysts were identical. Relevant characterization was conducted using XRF, ICP, XRD, N2 adsorption–desorption, SEM, TEM, CO-IR, H2-TPR and O2-TPD. The data show that the better catalytic performance of Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets is probably due to better accessibility of active sites, better reducibility of active Cu+ species, and the weakened interaction between oxygen and Cu+ sites. Keywords ZSM-5 nanosheets Cu-ZSM-5 N2O decomposition 1 Introduction Zeolites are an important family of aluminosilicates with ordered pore structures, high thermal stability, and diversified types. These properties make them useful in separation and catalysis. However, the crystallite sizes of zeolites are usually on the order of micrometers. The diffusion of molecules in and out of zeolites as well as the accessibility of active sites is constrained by the large crystallite size. To address this limitation, a lot of hierarchical zeolites with both micropores and mesopores (or macropores) have been synthesized [1–9]. Enhanced activities were obtained by the introduction of mesopores/macrospores, due to the better accessibility of active sites. The problem can also be overcome by reducing the thickness of the zeolites crystals, which reduces diffusion path lengths and thus improves molecular diffusion. This has been realized by synthesizing nanosheet zeolites. ZSM-5 nanosheets with high surface areas and short diffusion paths were synthesized using some specially designed surfactants [10–12]. These zeolites can be used directly as catalysts for the cracking of branched polyethylene [10], decalin [13], n-heptane [14], and n-octane [15], the conversion of methanol to hydrocarbons/gasoline [16–18], gas-phase Beckmann rearrangement [19], gas-phase isomerization and disproportionation of 1,2,4-trimethylbenzene [20], isomerization and hydrocracking of n-decane [21], and catalytic pyrolysis of cellulose, hemicelluloses, and lignin [22]. In addition, ZSM-5 nanosheets were also used as supports to make Pt/ZSM-5 nanosheets for the hydroisomerization of n-heptane [23] and MoO x /ZSM-5 nanosheets for direct methane conversion [24]. Heteroatoms can be incorporated into ZSM-5 nanosheets to design new catalysts. For instance, Fe-ZSM-5 nanosheets were tested in the selective oxidation of benzene with N2O [25] and the selective catalytic reduction of NO by ammonia [26]. Ti-ZSM-5 nanosheets were used in the epoxidation of olefins [27,28]. Sn-ZSM-5 nanosheets were used in the Baeyer–Villiger oxidation of cyclic ketones [29]. The presence of heteroatoms and the short diffusion path of the ZSM-5 nanosheets are both important factors for these reactions. In view of the interesting structure and properties of ZSM-5 nanosheets, it would be of great interest to further explore their catalytic applications. Here we report a case on the catalytic decomposition of N2O on Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets. N2O is a potent greenhouse gas and contributes to ozone layer depletion. N2O is usually eliminated by direct catalytic decomposition [30,31]. Metal cation-exchanged zeolites have been frequently used for catalytic decomposition of N2O [32–39]. In particular, Cu-ZSM-5 shows higher activity than Cu-FER, Cu-MOR, Cu-BEA, and Cu-Y [32]. In the present work, Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets were prepared by cation-exchange method, and their catalytic performance for decomposition of N2O was investigated and compared with that of conventional Cu-ZSM-5. Possible reasons for the better performance of Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets are discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation ZSM-5 nanosheets were prepared following the procedures in the literature [10], using [C18H37-N+(CH3)2-C6H12-N+(CH3)2-C6H13]Br2 (denoted as C18-6-6Br2) as a template. Typically, 0.36g NaOH was dissolved in 20ml deionized water, then 1.5gC18-6-6Br2 and 0.37g Al2(SO4)3·18H2O were added, and the mixture was agitated continuously at 60°C for 1h. Then 6.73g silica gel (25wt%) was added dropwise at room temperature, and the mixture was stirred at 60°C for 1h to obtain a gel with composition of 50 SiO2:Al2O3:8 Na2O:4 C18-6-6Br2:2000 H2O. The gel was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 150°C for 7 d. The product was filtered, washed with deionized water, dried at 120°C, and calcined at 550°C for 4h in air to remove the template. The obtained sample was exchanged with 1mol/l NaNO3 solution (with a solution/zeolite ratio of 10ml/g) at 80°C for 4h. The Si/Al ratio of the obtained Na-ZSM-5 nanosheets was determined by XRF as 39. 2g Na-ZSM-5 nanosheets were ion-exchanged in 41ml aqueous Cu(II) acetate (0.01mol/l). The ion-exchange procedure was repeated three times to ensure a full exchange (i.e., Cu/Al ratio=0.5) [40]. The sample was dried at 100 oC, and denoted as Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets. For comparison, conventional Cu-ZSM-5 with Si/Al molar ratio of 36 was prepared as follows. NH4-ZSM-5 from Zeolyst (CBV8040, Si/Al=36 measured by XRF) was calcined in static air at 450°C for 4h. The resulting H-ZSM-5 was ion-exchanged in 1mol/l NaNO3 solution with a solution/zeolite ratio of 10ml/g at 80°C for 4h. The ion-exchange procedure was repeated three times, and the obtained Na-ZSM-5 was exchanged by aqueous Cu(II) acetate as described above. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was carried out on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with nickel-filtered Cu Kα radiation. The bulk Si/Al ratios of Na-ZSM-5 sheets and conventional Na-ZSM-5 were measured by XRF on a Bruker-AXS S4 Explorer. The Cu content was determined by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) atomic emission spectroscopy using a Thermo Electron IRIS Intrepid II XSP spectrometer after dissolving the samples in HF. The BET surface areas and micropore volumes of samples were analyzed by N2 adsorption at −196°C using a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 instrument. Scanning electron micrograph (SEM) images were taken on Nova NanoSEM450 instruments. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were taken with a JEOL JEM-3010 with an accelerating voltage of 300kV. DRIFTS data were recorded on an FTIR (Nicolet 6700) equipped with an MCT detector cooled by liquid N2. The DRIFTS cell was fitted with CaF2 windows and a heating cartridge. Samples were activated in He at 150, 250 or 400°C for 2h, cooled to room temperature under flowing He (50ml/min), and treated in flowing 0.2vol.% CO–He mixture for 60min, then swept under the He flow for 60min, Spectra were collected at room temperature under flowing He, with a resolution of 4cm−1 and accumulation of 100 scans. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) profiles were obtained on a Micromeritics AutoChem II apparatus. The sample (100mg) was pretreated in He at 500°C for 2h, cooled to 50°C in He, and subsequently contacted with a H2/Ar mixture (10vol.% H2, 30ml/min). The temperature was ramped to 800 oC at a rate of 10°C/min. The H2 consumption was monitored using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). O2 temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) was carried out in a quartz reactor. The loaded sample (100mg) was pretreated with pure He (50ml/min) at 200°C for 2h, then cooled to room temperature. The ambient was switched to 5% O2/He (flow rate: 50ml/min), the catalyst was heated to 500°C at a rate of 10°C/min, and then kept at 500°C for 2h. After cooling down to room temperature, the ambient was switched to pure He (50ml/min) to remove physisorbed oxygen during the He purging for 1h. Finally, the catalyst was heated in He (50ml/min) to 550°C at a rate of 10°C/min and kept at 500°C for 20min. The desorbed oxygen was monitored by a TCD detector. 2.3 Catalytic testing The catalytic measurements for N2O decomposition were carried out in a fixed-bed flow reactor at atmospheric pressure [39]. Briefly, 0.2g catalyst (40–60 mesh) was loaded into a U-shaped glass tube (7mm i.d.), heated to 500°C at a rate of 10°C/min under flowing He (50ml/min), and held at 500°C for 2h. After cooling down to room temperature, 0.5% N2O/He (60ml/min) flowed through the catalyst for 1h, during which the concentration of N2O were periodically measured by GC (Agilent 7890A) that can separate N2O, N2, and O2. After reaching adsorption–desorption equilibrium, the difference in several consequent GC measurements was generally within 0.3%. The reaction temperature was then varied using a furnace and kept at various elevated temperatures for 30min in each temperature step. The existing stream was again periodically analyzed by the GC, and the conversion of N2O was calculated according to X =([N2O]in −[N2O]out)/[N2O]in, where [N2O]in refers to the N2O concentration or peak area at room temperature, and [N2O]out refers to the N2O concentration or peak area at an elevated temperature [39]. In order to study the influence of O2 on the catalytic activity, 5% O2 was added into the reaction mixture whereas the concentration of N2O was still 0.5%, and the total flow rate of the reaction mixture was still 60ml/min. To test the stability of catalysts, the N2O conversions on Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets and conventional Cu-ZSM-5 were measured as a function of time on stream. After pretreatment in He at 500°C, the catalyst was cooled to 475°C. The ambient was switched to 0.5% N2O/He, and the exiting stream was periodically analyzed by GC for 50h. Finally, the catalyst was cooled down while 0.5% N2O/He was still flowing. The [N2O]in was obtained when the catalyst was cooled and no N2O decomposition took place. 3 Results 3.1 Structural, morphological and textural properties Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets as well as conventional Cu-ZSM-5. Both samples exhibit diffraction peaks characteristic of MFI structure. For Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets, only the peaks at 2θ =7.87°, 8.80°, 20.34°, 23.08°, 23.90°, 29.93°, and 44.95° corresponding to crystal planes (101), (200), (103), (501), (303), (503), and (804) are obvious, whereas reflections corresponding to crystal planes in the b-direction are either broadened or missing, indicating that Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets possess wide a–c planes with large coherent domains, while the framework thickness along the b-axis is extremely small [10]. This is in clear contrast to the pattern of the conventional Cu-ZSM-5. Fig. 2 depicts the 27Al MAS NMR spectra. Both Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets and conventional Cu-ZSM-5 have an intense signal at 56ppm (assigned to framework Al in tetrahedral coordination) and a weak signal at 0ppm (assigned to extra-framework Al in octahedral coordination), showing that the majority of the Al species has been incorporated into the framework of the zeolites. Fig. 3 illustrates the SEM and TEM images of Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets. As seen in Fig. 3A, nanosheet zeolites show a lettuce-leaf-like morphology, and the size of the entire particle is about 500nm. The overall thickness of the lamellar stacking composing of ZSM-5 framework is normally about 20–30nm (Fig. 3B). In contrast, conventional Cu-ZSM-5 has many sphere-shaped particles with diameters in the range of 250–500nm and a few bigger granules (about 1μm) as shown in Fig. S1. Table 1 summarizes the chemical composition and textural properties of Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets, together with that of conventional Cu-ZSM-5. The Cu content is almost equivalent for the two samples. However, Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets possess a bit higher BET surface area and a much larger mesopore volume (410m2/g and 0.45cm3/g), compared with conventional Cu-ZSM-5 (381m2/g and 0.12cm3/g). 3.2 CO-IR IR spectroscopy of CO adsorbed on Cu-zeolites can be used to characterize the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+ ions in zeolites. Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets and conventional Cu-ZSM-5 were treated in He at different temperatures, and characterized by DRIFTS with CO as a probe at room temperature. Note that the data in Fig. 4 are from individual experiments using catalysts from the same batch, not time-dependent experiments. As shown in Fig. 4A, fresh Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets do not show any CO peaks. At this stage, Cu species exists in the form of Cu2+ whereas Cu2+ cannot be probed by CO-IR [41]. When Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets are treated in He at 150°C and above, then cooled down for CO adsorption, two peaks appear in the range of 2110–2170cm−1. The main band at 2156cm−1 is characteristic of Cu+-CO species on isolated Cu+ sites [42–44], and the shoulder at 2137cm−1 is assigned to CO adsorbed on dimeric Cu+ sites (Cu+-CO-Cu+ species) [45,46]. The intensities of two peaks increase with the increase of pretreatment temperature, indicating the conversion of Cu2+ species in the fresh Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets to Cu+ during thermal treatment in He. A similar spectrum was observed over conventional Cu-ZSM-5 treated in He at 400°C (trace c in Fig. 4B), indicating that conventional Cu-ZSM-5 undergoes the same reduction process upon thermal treatment. 3.3 H2-TPR The redox properties of Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets and conventional Cu-ZSM-5 were investigated by H2-TPR. The catalysts were pretreated in He at 500°C before conducting H2-TPR. Up to three reduction peaks can be distinguished (Fig. 5 , Table 2 ). In reference to other H2-TPR results in the literature [47–49], the peak around 110°C (peak I) can be assigned to the reduction of oxygen bridged Cu-dimers [Cu-O-Cu]2+ to Cu+; the weak peak around 240°C (peak II) is attributed to the reduction of isolated Cu2+ to Cu+ and the reduction of CuO to metallic Cu; the intense peak beyond 400°C (peak III) is due to the reduction of Cu+ to metallic Cu. The reduction temperature of peak III is obviously lower for Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets than for conventional Cu-ZSM-5, indicating that Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets exhibit a better reducibility of Cu+ species. Based on the H2 consumption of three reduction peaks, the amount of Cu+ species on samples pretreated in situ in He at 500°C were calculated and listed in Table 2. As expected, the amount of Cu+ on Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets is close to that on conventional Cu-ZSM-5. 3.4 O2-TPD Fig. 6 shows the O2-TPD profiles of Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets and conventional Cu-ZSM-5. The O2 desorption profiles were obtained in He flow by raising the temperature up to 550°C, and can be fitted into three peaks (Fig. 6, Table 3 ). The peaks around 110°C (Peak I) are assigned to molecular O2 chemisorption on Cu ions, and the peaks around 200°C (Peak II) are assigned to atomic O chemisorptions on Cu ions [50–52]. In addition to the above two main peaks, weak peaks (Peak III) are observed in the range of 300–500°C, assigned to desorption of extra-lattice oxygen in Cu-dimers (Cu2+-O-Cu2+) [43,50,51]. A comparison of two O2-TPD profiles shows that the desorption temperatures of peaks are obviously lower for Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets than for conventional Cu-ZSM-5 (Table 3), indicating that desorption of oxygen in Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets is easier. Since the desorption of adsorbed oxygen is reported to be important in N2O decomposition [32,52], the weak interaction between oxygen and Cu ion in Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets may facilitate N2O decomposition. 3.5 Catalytic decomposition of N2O N2O decomposition over Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets and conventional Cu-ZSM-5 was studied and the results are given in Fig. 7 . Comparisons were made under the same reaction conditions, as described in Section 2. The activities on both catalysts increase with the increase of reaction temperature, and Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets are apparently more active than conventional Cu-ZSM-5 with the identical Cu content. The N2O conversion of Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets reaches 71.7% at 450°C while the conversion over conventional Cu-ZSM-5 is only 48.7% under the same reaction condition. To test the effect of O2 on the catalytic activity, 5% O2 was added into the reaction mixture while the concentration of N2O and total flow rate of the reaction mixture remain unchanged. As shown in Fig. 7, O2 virtually has no effect on N2O decomposition for these Cu-ZSM-5 type catalysts, in accordance with other reports [53,54]. The N2O decomposition reaction has been run continuously on these Cu-ZSM-5 catalysts for 50h and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . It can be seen that Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets are quite stable on stream. The N2O conversion at 475°C maintains at ca. 80% without any observable trend of deactivation in 50h. In contrast, the N2O conversion over conventional Cu-ZSM-5 decreased gradually with the time, from initial 74% to 54% after 50h. CO-IR characterization (Fig. 4B and Table 3) show that the CO adsorption peaks of the spent Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets decreases slightly as compared with those of the fresh one, while the CO-IR peaks of the spent conventional Cu-ZSM-5 are obviously smaller than that of the fresh one, indicating the decrease in the number of active Cu+ sites after prolonged use of conventional Cu-ZSM-5 [53]. There could be some oxidation of a portion of Cu+ by the O2 (produced from N2O decomposition) at 475°C. 4 Discussion Cu-containing zeolites have been widely investigated in direct N2O decomposition. The Cu sites in these catalysts are believed to act as active sites although the nature of these sites remains unclear. In the present work, the Cu amount of Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets and conventional Cu-ZSM-5 is identical (Table 1) due to their similar Si/Al ratio. In situ DRIFTS characterization revealed that the reduction of Cu2+ to isolated Cu+ and dimeric Cu+ species occurs on both zeolites during the thermal treatment in He at 150°C and above. Quantitative determination of isolated Cu+ and dimeric Cu+ was derived from the integrated areas of the IR band at ca. 2156cm−1 and 2137cm−1, the results are almost same for Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets and conventional Cu-ZSM-5 (Table 4 ). Note that monovalent copper (Cu+) in zeolites is commonly regarded as the active sites for N2O decomposition [41,56–60]. Thus, the content of active sites on these two catalysts is also very close. However, Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets show higher activity than conventional Cu-ZSM-5 in N2O decomposition (Fig. 7). The difference in activity may come from the different morphology and structure of the two zeolites. Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets have higher surface area (410m2/g) and larger mesoporous volume (0.45cm3/g) than conventional Cu-ZSM-5 (381m2/g and 0.12cm3/g). Kustova et al. [55] reported that the introduction of mesoporosity into conventional Cu-ZSM-5 led to a significant improvement of the activity in NO decomposition, as ascribed to the better accessibility of the active Cu sites. In our case, better accessibility of active sites in Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets is also expected. The chemical properties of the active Cu sites on two zeolites are also different. H2-TPR data confirmed that the reducibility of Cu+ species on Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets is much better than that on conventional Cu-ZSM-5 (Fig. 5), leading to the higher activity of nanosheet catalyst. In the literature, the better activity of catalysts in N2O decomposition was sometimes correlated to the reduction behaviors of catalysts (as shown by H2-TPR) [61–66]. This is not to say the catalysts are reduced prior to reaction testing, nor does that mean the catalysts operate in the presence of H2. Rather, the better reducibility means the weakening of the M-O binds, which is important for N2O decomposition. O2-TPD profiles show desorption of oxygen from the Cu sites on Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets is easier than on conventional Cu-ZSM-5 (Table 4). The desorption of adsorbed oxygen is thought to be important for N2O decomposition [32,52], therefore, the more facile release of oxygen from Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets would further facilitates N2O decomposition. Our catalysis data also show the better stability of Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets than conventional Cu-ZSM-5 (Fig. 8). The CO-IR data show the dominance of Cu+ for the He-activated catalysts and the catalysts collected after reaction, indicating the active site is indeed Cu+. In addition, the amount of Cu+ species in Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets remains almost unchanged after 50h reaction, whereas the amount of Cu+ species in conventional Cu-ZSM-5 decrease obviously (see also Table 4), probably due to the oxidation of a portion of Cu+ by O2 (produced by N2O) at 475°C. These data explain the difference in stability of these two catalysts. Note that the above are empirical observations, and it is still not quite clear why the reduction behavior, O2 desorption behavior, and stability of Cu+ are different with different Cu-ZSM-5 catalysts. It may be tempting to ascribe the differences in these properties to the structural and morphological differences of Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets and conventional Cu-ZSM-5. Further inputs from theoretical calculations and mechanistic studies are still needed to better understand the difference. 5 Conclusions Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets showed higher activity than conventional Cu-ZSM-5 in N2O decomposition. The active Cu sites in former catalyst are more accessible due to nanosheet structure of its support. H2-TPR data indicate that the active Cu+ species in Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets has better reducibility. More facile desorption of oxygen from Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets was observed. These findings correlate very well with the N2O decomposition performance. Additionally, Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets exhibited much better stability than conventional Cu-ZSM-5. Acknowledgments W. Hua and Y. coredata.dc:description: ZSM-5 nanosheets were prepared using [C18H37-N+(CH3)2-C6H12-N+(CH3)2-C6H13]Br2 as a template and then ion-exchanged with Cu cations. The catalytic performance of the obtained Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets in N2O decomposition was investigated and compared with that of conventional Cu-ZSM-5. Higher activity as well as better stability was observed for Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets although the Cu contents of the catalysts were identical. Relevant characterization was conducted using XRF, ICP, XRD, N2 adsorption–desorption, SEM, TEM, CO-IR, H2-TPR and O2-TPD. The data show that the better catalytic performance of Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets is probably due to better accessibility of active sites, better reducibility of active Cu+ species, and the weakened interaction between oxygen and Cu+ sites.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic decomposition of N2O over Cu-ZSM-5 nanosheets
